Quinoa & Black Bean Salad

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to your next favorite dish: Quinoa & Black Bean Salad! This vibrant, protein-packed salad is not only a feast for the eyes with its colorful ingredients, but it also caters to a variety of dietary preferences, making it a perfect choice for everyone—from vegans to gluten-free eaters. Quinoa, often hailed as a superfood, brings a delightful nuttiness and a hearty texture, while the black beans add a substantial dose of fiber and protein. Tossed together with fresh cherry tomatoes, crunchy red bell pepper, sweet corn, and aromatic cilantro, this salad is bursting with flavor and nutrition. Whether you’re preparing a light lunch, a side dish for a barbecue, or a meal prep option for the week ahead, this Quinoa & Black Bean Salad is versatile and easy to make. Ready to dive into this deliciously refreshing recipe? Let’s get started!

Ingredients

quinoa

Rinse quinoa thoroughly before cooking to remove saponins, which can give it a bitter taste. If you don't have quinoa, you can substitute it with bulgur, couscous, or even rice, but adjust the cooking time accordingly.

black beans (canned, drained and rinsed)

Canned black beans are convenient, but make sure to rinse them well to reduce sodium content. If you're using dried black beans, soak them overnight and cook until tender before adding. Consider using kidney beans or pinto beans as alternatives.

cherry tomatoes (halved)

Choose ripe, firm cherry tomatoes for the best flavor. If cherry tomatoes aren't available, you can substitute with grape tomatoes or regular tomatoes diced into small pieces. Roasting them slightly before adding can enhance their sweetness.

red bell pepper (diced)

Red bell peppers add sweetness and crunch; choose firm ones without blemishes. If you prefer a different flavor, you can substitute with yellow or orange bell peppers. For a spicier kick, you can use jalapeños or serrano peppers.

red onion (diced)

Red onions have a mild flavor, making them great for salads. If you prefer a milder taste, soak the diced onion in cold water for 10 minutes before adding. You can substitute with green onions or shallots for different flavor profiles.

corn (canned or frozen)

If using canned corn, drain and rinse it to remove excess sodium. Frozen corn can be heated briefly or added directly to the salad. Fresh corn off the cob can also be used for a sweeter taste; just blanch it briefly.

fresh cilantro (chopped)

Cilantro adds a fresh, herby flavor. If you're not a fan of cilantro, try substituting with parsley, basil, or mint for a different flavor twist. Make sure to chop it finely to distribute its flavor evenly.

lime juice

Fresh lime juice provides acidity and brightness; use fresh limes for the best flavor. If you don't have lime, lemon juice is a good substitute. You can also add lime zest for an extra citrusy kick.

olive oil

Use high-quality extra virgin olive oil for the best flavor. If you want a different flavor profile, consider using avocado oil or a flavored oil like garlic-infused oil.

salt

Start with a small amount of salt and adjust to taste, as canned ingredients may already contain salt. For added flavor, consider using sea salt or kosher salt.

black pepper

Freshly ground black pepper enhances the overall flavor; consider using white pepper for a subtler taste. If you prefer a different heat level, try adding crushed red pepper flakes for some spice.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Rinse the Quinoa

    Start by rinsing 1 cup of quinoa under cold running water. This process helps to remove any natural coating called saponin, which can impart a bitter taste to your dish. Use a fine mesh strainer for best results.

  • Step 2: Cook the Quinoa

    In a medium saucepan, combine the rinsed quinoa with 2 cups of water. Bring the mixture to a boil over medium-high heat. Once boiling, reduce the heat to low, cover the saucepan, and let it simmer for about 15 minutes. The quinoa is done when it has absorbed all the water and is fluffy.

  • Step 3: Let it Sit

    After cooking, remove the saucepan from heat and let it sit covered for an additional 5 minutes. This allows the quinoa to steam, enhancing its texture. After 5 minutes, fluff the quinoa with a fork to separate the grains.

  • Step 4: Prepare the Vegetables

    While the quinoa is cooling, prepare your vegetables. Dice 1 red bell pepper and 1/4 cup of red onion, and halve 1 cup of cherry tomatoes. If using frozen corn, thaw it beforehand. If using canned corn, simply drain it.

  • Step 5: Combine Ingredients

    In a large mixing bowl, combine the fluffed quinoa, 1 can (15 oz) of drained and rinsed black beans, the prepared cherry tomatoes, diced red bell pepper, diced red onion, and corn. Add 1/4 cup of freshly chopped cilantro for flavor and freshness.

  • Step 6: Make the Dressing

    In a small bowl, whisk together 3 tablespoons of lime juice, 2 tablespoons of olive oil, and season with salt and black pepper to taste. This simple dressing will enhance the flavors of your salad.

  • Step 7: Toss the Salad

    Pour the dressing over the quinoa and vegetable mixture. Toss gently to combine all ingredients thoroughly, ensuring the dressing evenly coats the salad.

  • Step 8: Serve or Chill

    You can serve the salad immediately for a fresh experience, or chill it in the fridge for an hour to let the flavors meld together. This salad is versatile and can be enjoyed on its own or as a side dish!

Frequently Asked Questions

What is quinoa and how do I prepare it?

Quinoa is a nutritious grain-like seed that's high in protein. To prepare it, rinse 1 cup of quinoa under cold water to remove any bitterness. Then, combine it with 2 cups of water in a saucepan, bring to a boil, reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for about 15 minutes until fluffy.

How can I tell when quinoa is cooked?

Quinoa is cooked when all the water is absorbed and the grains have expanded to form little spirals. Let it sit covered for 5 minutes after cooking, then fluff with a fork.

What can I substitute for black beans?

If you don't have black beans, you can use chickpeas, kidney beans, or pinto beans as alternatives. Just make sure to drain and rinse canned versions.

How do I safely cut vegetables?

To safely cut vegetables, use a sharp knife and a cutting board. Keep your fingers curled under your knuckles to avoid cutting yourself, and always slice away from your body.

How do I store leftovers of the quinoa salad?

Store leftovers in an airtight container in the fridge. It will stay fresh for about 3-4 days. You may want to add a little extra lime juice or olive oil before serving to refresh the flavors.

What is the best way to mix the salad without mashing the ingredients?

Use a gentle folding motion with a large spoon or spatula to mix the salad. Start from the bottom and lift the ingredients rather than stirring vigorously.

How can I make the salad more filling?

To make the salad more filling, consider adding some diced avocado, grilled chicken, or feta cheese for added protein and richness.

How do I measure ingredients accurately?

For dry ingredients like quinoa, use a dry measuring cup. For liquids, use a liquid measuring cup. To measure sticky ingredients like honey or peanut butter, lightly oil the measuring cup first.

What if I don’t have fresh cilantro?

If you don’t have fresh cilantro, you can use parsley or omit it entirely. The salad will still taste great!

How can I adjust the flavor of the dressing?

Feel free to adjust the lime juice, olive oil, salt, and pepper to your taste. If you like it tangier, add more lime juice; for a richer flavor, increase the olive oil.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

This salad is gluten-free and vegan, making it suitable for a variety of dietary preferences. For a low-carb option, replace quinoa with cauliflower rice. You can also add or substitute ingredients based on availability, such as using different beans (like kidney or pinto) or incorporating seasonal vegetables. For a spicier kick, consider adding diced jalapeños or a sprinkle of cayenne pepper.

Pairings

This Quinoa & Black Bean Salad pairs wonderfully with grilled chicken or shrimp for a protein boost. For a vegetarian option, consider adding feta cheese or avocado for creaminess. As for beverages, a chilled Sauvignon Blanc or a refreshing lemonade complements the salad's flavors nicely. For a non-alcoholic option, try iced green tea or a sparkling water with lime.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the salad in a large, colorful bowl to showcase the vibrant ingredients. Garnish with additional cilantro and lime wedges for a fresh touch. This dish is perfect for potlucks or casual gatherings, served as a side dish or a light main course. For a more substantial meal, serve alongside tortilla chips or in a wrap with additional toppings like avocado or salsa.

Quinoa & Black Bean Salad

35 min
$10
350 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Dietary Tags:

VegetarianVeganGluten-Free

Cuisine:

AmericanMexican

Course:

MainSide Dish

Tags:

SaladHealthyEasyQuick

Description

A vibrant and nutritious salad packed with protein, fiber, and fresh flavors, perfect for any meal.

Ingredients

  • quinoa: 1 cup
  • black beans (canned, drained and rinsed): 1 can (15 oz)
  • cherry tomatoes (halved): 1 cup
  • red bell pepper (diced): 1
  • red onion (diced): 1/4 cup
  • corn (canned or frozen): 1 cup
  • fresh cilantro (chopped): 1/4 cup
  • lime juice: 3 tablespoons
  • olive oil: 2 tablespoons
  • salt: to taste
  • black pepper: to taste
